topics.topic: Patient is a 45-year-old male with a history of anaplastic astrocytoma in the spine and severe weakness in the lower extremities and complications of Foley catheter urinary retention, high-dose steroids, hypertension and chronic pain. The tumor is located on the T-L spine, an anaplastic astrocytoma that cannot be removed by radiation. It's complicated by progressive lower-extremity weakness and urinary retention. The patient initially presented with RLE, which is difficulty walking in the right knee and numbness in the right frontal lobe. MRI showed a spinal cord cone mass that was biopsied and found to be an anaplastic astrocytoma. Treatment included t10-l1 area radiation followed by 11 rounds of temozolomide for 7 days on and 7 days off. This was followed by Avastin Q2 weeks/2 weeks, with a CPT-11 x4 rest and repeat cycle per week.

In the story HT, a 48-year-old smoker with hyperlipidemia and bicuspid aortic stenosis, went to the cardiologist with complaints of progressive respiratory distress and lower extremity edema on [**2148-10-1**] date. TTE was found to be severe aortic stenosis and worsened LV function. His right ventricular pressure was 41 and he had a biatrial dilation. He was diagnosed with mild MR (mitral regurgitation) and second-degree aortic insufficiency. He was sent home from the cardiology clinic with Lasix and BB{\beta blocker} (couldn't tolerate it), SOB{\shortness of breath} and LE{\lower extremity} (feed) continued to deteriorate and was finally brought here for evaluation. Repeated echocardiography during this stay confirmed left ventricular hypertrophy, cavitation dilation and severe global hypokinesia, severe aortic stenosis with the bicuspid aortic valve underlying, dilated aortic outlet and critical aortic stenosis showing mild pulmonary arterial systolic hypertension. The patient was given a preoperative CT scan of the chest for preoperative cap replacement and a preoperative examination with carotid US (medium heterogeneous plaque and bilateral 1-39% ICA ((Internal Carotid Arter) narrowing). Cardiac catheterization was also performed in combination with right-heart catheterization to assess pulmonary artery pressures, and angiographically no flow-limiting coronary artery disease was detected.

A 32-year-old woman came in complaining of a severe "exploding" headache. He and his wife reported that he was in the kitchen yesterday when he got up and hit his head on the corner of a cabinet. The next morning, I suddenly had a "blasting" headache. When he arrived at the hospital, his brain CT showed a significant amount of blood in his right ventricle. The NSGY assessed the patient for spontaneous intraventricular bleeding with concern for an underlying vascular malformation. Cerebral angiography showed abnormal vascularization with a drainage vein that penetrates deep white matter from the left temporal lobe and is consistent with AVM. The patient's headaches continued, but they were getting better with painkillers. The patient refused physical therapy evaluation, but was able to walk independently without any problems. He was released to his home with his wife on [**2155-12-6**].

A 44-year-old woman with a history of PCOS, obesity and hypertension came in with symptoms of cholecystitis and was accidentally diagnosed with a large pericardial effusion. Pericardiosynthesis was performed, and the fluid analysis was consistent with Burkitt's lymphoma. The pericardial fluid was cappa light chain restricted CD10 positive monotypic B cells, which represented rearrangement of FMC-7, CD19, CD20 and MYC compatible with Burkitt lymphoma. The subsequent lumbar puncture and bone marrow biopsy were negative for any traces, indicating the condition as primary cardiac lymphoma. Cardiac MRI showed a mass of 3 cm x 1 cm in the lateral wall of the right atrium adjacent to the AV junction. Medical history: one. Rare migraine two. High blood pressure 3. Obesity is 4. PKOS/infertility is 5. Viral encephalitis/meningitis-->ICH (Intracerebral hemorrhage)-->seizure/infarction ([**2137**]) =- Caused by severe sinus infection, which causes mild nonfocal residual deficits 6. CSF leak with meningitis with the installation of lumbar drainage 7. R LE DVT ((Deep Vein Thrombosis in the Right Lower Extremity) with the placement of an IVC (Inferior Vena Cava) filter 8. Knee surgery .

A 74-year-old male patient with a history of post-coronary artery disease CABG (Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery), EF 60% and previous CVA (no permanent deficit), hypertension, HL (Hiperlipidemia), Type 2 DM, moderate to severe PVD (Peripheral Vascular Disease) was referred to cardiology for PVD evaluation and examination found that the patient had carotid bloating. After further examination of the symptoms, the patient reported: + Occasional dizziness, no previous syncope, occasional HA (headache), CP (cerebral palsy) /SOB (shortness of breath). No sensory or motor defects. He remembers maybe 10 or 15 years ago, he had a stroke with no permanent deficit. Before the CABG, it was just sweating. In a more detailed examination of the systems, it is noteworthy that there is no chest pain, exertional dyspnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, torsion, syncope or presyncope. A carotid US was performed and significant bilateral carotid stenosis was seen (Left to right). An angiogram found 80% narrowing in the R ICA (Right Inter carotid Artery) and 90% narrowing in the L ICA (Left Inter carotid Artery). Cerebral angiography also found that the right ACA (Anterior Cerebral Artery) and the right MCA (Middle Cerebral Artery) were open, and the left ACA and left MCA were open. Previous medical history: [**2154**] at ([**Hospital 1 112**]) coronary artery disease after coronary artery bypass surgery (CABG) Previous SVO Bilateral carotid artery disease Anemia PVD ((Peripheral Vascular Disease) Hypertension Diabetes-related retinopathy and peripheral neuropathy After surgery cataract Thyroid nodule After resection of colon polyps Intermittent low back pain Proteinuria Fracture of the right thumb in childhood Arthritis

The 55-year-old woman, who was undergoing treatment for HD (Hemodializ) and peritoneal dialysis for recent renal failure (ESRD), complained of dehydration, bloodless diarrhea and weakness. He has two history of Clostridium difficile infection, the last one was just a month ago. He took antibiotics in the last month of his previous incarceration. He was also treated with oral vancomycin for 14 days for Cdiff during that time. The patient was initially admitted to the intensive care unit and was septic until the morning of [**8-26**], had leukocytosis but no fever, and was given vasopressor therapy. The C-diff test at the hospital was positive, and the patient had leukocytosis consistent with C-diff. The patient was initially treated with Vanco po, Flagyl IV and Flagyl po, and was switched to Vanco oral and Flagyl oral in [**8-29**] as the patient recovered. The patient was treated with Vanco for a prolonged period of 6 weeks due to recurrent C diff. The patient was advised to take probiotics and disinfect his home with bleach after discharge.

A 60-year-old male patient with hepatitis C, stage II esophageal inheritance, who was recently hospitalized due to UGIB (Upper Gastrointestinal Bleeding) due to [**2-9**] NSAID gastritis, was referred by the hepatology clinic for emergency admission due to a newly-occurring speech disorder and a process of impulsive thinking. The patient also states that he experienced a new imbalance that led to a fall, which may have hit his head. According to the latest report of the liver clinic, he has not used ETOH (Ethyl Alcohol) for a year (confirmed with the patient), the General urine toxicology test (utox) for alcohol was negative. BT was within normal limits, and neurological evaluation determined it wasn't an ischemic heart attack. The patient was diagnosed with hepatic encephalopathy and started lactulose therapy. Liver function tests have shown a dramatic increase in total and direct bilirubin since your last visit. Another worrying feature was the increase in the patient's AFP. This may have been the cause of the progression of the cirrhosis, as the two interferon treatments failed. He's gonna be followed closely to investigate. HCV Syndrome (two failed treatment with interferon) Portal Gastropathy II. The degree of endoscopic varices HTN Final sedation [**4-/2150**]: UGIB (Upper Gastrointestinal Bleeding) [**2-9**] Gastritis caused by NSAIDs

He's a 57-year-old gentleman with CLL and a large cellular transformation. She was treated for high white blood cell count and LDH on 10/21. At the time, he didn't have any splenomegaly or cytopenia. He had some major lymphadenopathy. He then completed four FCR cycles in 09/[**2119**]. She responded to the treatment perfectly and was followed for about two years without treatment. He then presented with an elevated white blood cell count at [**7-/2122**], approximately 50% lymphocytes, and mildly elevated LDH. He also had lymphadenopathy, which worsened slightly on manual examination. He then received four rounds of PCR, but could not get much in terms of response, and the treatment regimen was transferred to R-CVP, where he received two rounds. Again, he did not get a significant response, but continued to show excellent performance status and was eventually transferred to Campath treatment. He improved his lymphocytosis and his white blood cell count dropped significantly, but it didn't have much effect on reducing his major lymphadenopathy. Eventually, the left cervical lymph node developed, and a biopsy was done, and it was found to have a Richter transformation.

A 41-year-old male patient with severe mental impairment, history of congestive heart failure (CHF) and epilepsy, was referred to NH (Nursing Home) with numbness and widespread trembling in his right face and received 20 mg of valium to stop seizure activity. The patient receiving outside medical care was thought to have secondary generalized focal epilepsy, probably due to anoxic brain injury at birth and associated with atrophic changes seen on MRI, especially in the left temporal lobe. The patient first had a seizure at age 13 and was diagnosed by her family as having generalized convulsions. Two years after the first attack, he had a second attack. Dilantin and phenobarbital continued. The patient hasn't had another seizure in 20 years. Recently, Dilantin was reduced and it was thought that it might be necessary to keep him out of seizures. The patient had no other events during the hospital stay and was back to baseline when discharged. Full EEG reports are expected during dictation. Medical history: Epilepsy as above, congestive heart failure, depression

Patient is a 22-year-old, healthy female with a five-year history of systemic mastocytosis. Normally, there are three outbreaks a year, and the patient with the fever and the gallstones comes in with a new outbreak. This is the third flare-up in two months while the patient is on the new steroid-lowering treatment. In addition to continued home treatment, he responded well to a 125 mg IV steroid and IV diphenhydram per 8 hours. His CBC was baseline and differential normal. His serum triptase is up to 84. The patient failed the aspirin test because of a negative reaction. IV steroids and IV benadryl stabilized her condition and transferred her back to the med bay. She continued to use the histamine receptor blockers she had been using at home and switched from IV treatment to PO steroids and benadryl and was kept under observation for one night and discharged with the medications she was using at home, reduced prednisone, calcium and vitamin D for GI prophylaxis and SS bactrim for PPI and PCP (pneumocystis pneumonia).

A 75-year-old male patient, diagnosed with metastatic papillary thyroid cancer and treated with 19 sessions of XRT (radiotherapy), presented with increased dysphagia for 2 days, poor oral intake, 9 pounds of weight loss in the last few weeks, and some lethargic complaints. Papillary thyroid cancer diagnosed with right cervical mass -- then cervical mass resection; thyroidectomy not performed -- high risk of bleeding, proximity to trachea and recurrent laryngeal nerve and large tumor size -- then cervical XRT -- then RAI ablation -- metastasis to lymph nodes and adrenal glands * then hernia repair * then tonsillectomy

A 34-year-old female patient with Marfan syndrome and known severe mitral valve prolapse and regurgitation was scheduled for MV repair but was dropped from follow-up. Her symptoms are continuing, and she's now ready to have mitral valve repair/replacement surgery. The EF in transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is 65%. Medical history: Marfan syndrome MVP Gastric reflux disease with severe mitral insufficiency History of gestational diabetes Hypertension in pregnancy Obesity 2 Caesarean Laser eye surgery Cataract surgery Foot surgery (reduction of bone length)

A 62-year-old male patient with a history of stroke (SVO), who had a permanent suprapubic catheter due to neurogenic bladder and had been hospitalized many times previously due to urinary tract infection (UTI), mental status change and urosepsis, again applied to the hospital with a urosepsis table. Her urosepsis has resolved after the vanc/meropenem treatment. There's a stone in the left ureter that doesn't cause a blockage, no evidence of urethral stricture. There's a significant leak in the suprapubic catheter area. She started on ditropan, switched to detrol. The urologist isn't worried about the leak, and he's gonna see the patient next week. Diagnosis at 03 (followed by R-CHOP x 6 weeks) Bells' palsy BPH Hypertension Partial bowel obstruction followed by colostomy Hepatitis C Cryoglobulinemia Transverse myelitis SLE, anti-dsDNA Ab+ Insulin-dependent Diabetic Fungal Myelogenesis Stage IV? Urinary tract infections - psedomonas and enterococcus

A 70-year-old patient with [**2132-8-24**] initially diagnosed with 2.5-3.5 L O2 with COPD, OSA (obstructive sleep apnea) and obesity hypoventilation syndrome, dCHF (decompensatory chronic heart failure), currently has a mental state that varies with agitation and hypoxia and O2 saturation with 5 L BipAp (Biphasic Positive Airway Pressure) in the 70s. The patient was agitated at first, then fell asleep. His daughter has reported increased agitation and altered mental status for the past two or three days while her O2 saturation was in the 60s and 70s. Her daughter also noticed that she had increased lower respiratory tract edema and weight gain, which caused her to call her GP and increase the dose of lasix from 80 mg daily to 100 mg daily, resulting in a slight improvement in edema. At home, he experienced a decrease in appetite, PO intake, and energy levels, and he experienced difficulty in daily activities. Except for chronic right hip pain that's been going on for the last 1-2 months, he has no fever, cough, tremor, excretion of sputum, cerebral palsy (CP), abdominal pain, or any other complaint. My daughter also reports a response to medication and BiPap at night. Previous medical history: - CAH; [**2119**] with 4 vascular coronary artery bypass grafting - CKY; EF %55, mild AS (aortic stenosis) - obesity hypoventilation syndrome - obstructive sleep apnea - DM2 - ventricular tachycardia; [**2127**] with ICD (implantable cardioverter defibrillator) grafting - hypothyroidism - schizophrenia - COAH - [**Hospital 1**] with pneumonia treatment at [**4-7**] where he was treated for a heart attack

A 70-year-old woman with a history of coronary artery disease recently noticed a lump in her abdomen and is presenting with fever/trembling and bandemia. For several weeks before he was hospitalized, he had a pain in his midsection that spread to his left kidney. It's been going on all day, it doesn't increase with food, but it does with vomiting and it gets worse with coughing. Later on [**4-20**] a CT of the uncontrasted abdomen was taken and a large, heterogeneous mass measuring 9.5 x 7.5 x 6.0 cm was seen in the upper left abdomen. The patient was given an EUS (Endoscopic Usg) with a biopsy. The biopsy results were consistent with pancreatic adenocarcinoma at the beginning of the pancreas. A splenic curvature/pancreatic tail mass was also seen in BT; given the patient's recent history of diverticulitis, it was likely diverticular apse; this was thought to be fluid buildup or abscess in the infection. The patient was administered IV antibiotics (Zosyn, followed by ceftriaxone and flagyl) and will continue these treatments until seen by ID (Infection Patients) as a standing patient. Medical history: one. Coronary artery disease 2. He had a history of angioplasty in [State 108] a year ago. Mitral valve prolapse is 3. Atrial fibrillation is 4. Hyperlipidemia is 5. High blood pressure 6. Chronic renal disease (SCr 2.1 [**3-17**]), which is 7. Hypothyroidism? What is it? (TSH 10 at [**3-17**]) 8. The following table shows the number of patients with the disease: The following table shows the number of cases of anaemia in the United Kingdom.

A 79-year-old female patient with COPD, who is thought to have multifactorial chronic hypoxemia and dyspnea associated with diastolic CF, who is thought to have chronic ASD-related pulmonary hypertension and who was undergoing 5L home oxygen therapy, was admitted to hospital with worsening respiratory distress. The cardiology consultation recommended right-heart catheterization to assess the response to sildenafil, but the patient declined. Pulmonary consultation recommended trying an empiric sildenafil due to severe dyspnoea symptoms that prevented treatment on the feet, and the patient tolerated treatment in bed without hypotension. The patient should consult with the pulmonologist to initiate chronic sildenafil as stand-up therapy when previously authorised. Past Medical History: - Atrial septal defect repair [**6-17**], complicated by sinus arrest with the placement of PPM. - Diastolic CHF ((Congestive Heart Failure), estimated dry weight 94 kg - Pulmonary Hypertension (RSVP ((Right Ventricular Systolic Pressure) 75 [**11-24**]) is considered secondary to long-term ASD - O2 at home (5L NC) with COPD, basal saturation in this treatment is lower than the high 80s than the high 90s. - OSA, CPAP is not compatible - Mild mitral insufficiency - Microsyther anemia - Hypothyroidism - followed by APPY (Appendectomy), followed by CCY (Cholecystectomy) ([**33**]) - Gallstone pancreatitis, followed by ERCP, sphincterotomy - High alkaline phosphate secondary to amiodarone

A 64-year-old woman with multiple myeloma with allogeneic transplantation, recurrent disease and systemic amyloidosis (lung, tongue, bladder, heart arrest) who was on hemodialysis for end-stage renal failure (ESRD). The patient has been hospitalized for two days with complaints of weakness, weakness and widespread body pain. She was hospitalized last week for hypercalcemia and has been treated with 30 mg of pamidronate, calcitonin and dialysis. The patient was initially treated with melphalan and prednisone, followed by VAD therapy and autologous stem cell transplantation. Upon the recurrence of her myeloma, she was started on thalidomide velcade and thalidomide, but these treatments were also discontinued due to the worsening of her edema and kidney function.

He's a 78-year-old male patient with BPH who's had multiple urological procedures, including a suprapubic prostatectomy. He has a low urine output and a bladder scan found 360 cc of residual urine. There's no way the staff could have put a foley on the probe. He consulted with the urologist, had a flexible cystoscope done in the ICU, and found a severe 2 cm bulbar urethral stricture. They were able to put a small catheter in and leave it in place. The patient had leakage around the catheter, the catheter was eventually removed, but the urine output continued to be good, and post-urination bladder scans were done every 4 hours to make sure there was no high residual volume. Urology has recommended that when the patient's condition is stable, he be taken to the operating room for surgical correction of the constriction.

A 65-year-old male patient with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and previously MI (myocardial infarction), HL (hyperlipidemia), HT (hypertension), ventricular tachycardia and syncope was admitted to hospital earlier today for evaluation of syncope and ventricular arrhythmia. Recently discharged after a negative study for Senkop, which included the implantation of a cardiac monitoring device. Assessed in OSH (outside the hospital) and according to yesterday's report, a bradycardia with a VT of 40 seconds and then a 39-beat number on the monitor was seen shortly after, which was consistent with the patient's symptoms. The patient went to monomorphic VT on telemetry one night. The patient was found to be unresponsive. CPR was initiated, but it was unclear if the patient had a pulse. Within a minute, the patient was back in sinus rhythm. The patient reports no symptoms prior to this episode. Right now, the patient is feeling a presenchymal and abdominal nausea, but she says she has no chest pain. The patient will be transferred to the CCU for catheterization and EPS (Electrophysiology study (EP study)).

A 35-year-old woman came in with a history of acne and mild hirsutism. Initial evaluation showed that he had high testosterone levels. Recently, she noticed that her hands and feet were getting bigger, and her ring was starting to look small on her finger. There was some irregularity in the menstrual cycle and some discharge from the nipple. He also had a history of snoring and headaches. Physical examination showed slight facial features that suggest acromegaly and prognathism. Their visual fields were normal with contrast. Hirsutism, soft tissue thickening, diaphoresis in the hands and feet. In laboratory evaluation in the fasted state, IGF-1 was found to be 968 ng/mL and random GH 19.7 ng/mL. The MRI showed a noninvasive macroadenoma. He's been using octreotide LAR at steady doses since his diagnosis was confirmed. Married with two kids. She uses IUDs as a form of birth control.

Patient is a 57-year-old male with abdominal pain and vomiting. The pain started slowly in the epigastric and periumbilical areas about 20 hours ago and spread to his back. He consumes about 60 units of alcohol a week and smokes 22 cigarettes a day. A healthy patient with no history of allergies or any history of medication use. Family history (father and sister) is positive for type 2 diabetes. She lives alone and has no children. Your wife is delicate and soft. His bowel sounds are normal. His heart rate is 115 beats per minute and his blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. Laboratory results found leukocytosis (19.5), urea 8.5, high CRP (145), high amylase (1200) and GLc (Glucose) level as 15. The CT scan is negative for obstructive pancreatitis.

Patient is a 31-year-old female with a complaint of abdominal pain. The pain started last night as a common abdominal discomfort. There was also loss of appetite and weakness. The pain became more and more intense and sharper in the morning. The pain was localized to the right lower quadrant this morning. His fever's within normal limits, and his vitals are normal. Focal sensitivity and defenses were observed during palpation in the right lower quadrant. Palpation in the left lower quadrant causes pain in the right. The lab results show a remarkable leukocytosis. Contrast CT scan of the abdominal area shows the presence of an enlarged appendix with thickened appendix wall without perforation, abscess or gangrene. He's a candidate for a laparoscopic appendectomy under general anesthesia.

A 39-year-old male came to the clinic with a cough and shortness of breath that wouldn't pass through an inhaler. These symptoms have been present for five days in the last two weeks. He doubled his oral corticosteroids last week. He was a cook with a history of asthma for three years, frequent coughing, wheezing, shortness of breath and chest tightness. The symptoms became more uncomfortable within one to two hours of starting work each day, and worsened throughout the work week. Her symptoms would improve in an hour or two outside of work. The spirometry performed revealed that the forced expiratory volume (FEV1) in the first second was 63% of the predicted one. His medical history says he had seasonal allergic rhinitis in the summer. He doesn't smoke or do drugs. Family history says his father and sister had asthma. He's currently on an inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) and 500 mcg of fluticasone/50 mcg of salmeterol, sprayed twice a day.

The patient is a 55-year-old male who has been visiting his family physician for the past 9 months due to lower urinary tract symptoms such as frequent urination, feeling of tightness, poor urine flow, incomplete ejaculation and intermittent urine flow. Further evaluation revealed: IPSS score: 15 Residual urine after urination: 70 mL Prostate volume (TRUS): 60 mL Prostate specific antigen (PSA) level: 3.2 ng/mL Urine volume 130 mL while maximum flow rate 10 mL/s He is otherwise healthy and uses only 1000 units of Vitamin D per day. The last blood chemistry (3 days ago) was normal: Hgb: 13.5 g/dl WBC: 135000 /mm3 Plt: 350000 /ml PT: 11 seconds PTT: 35 seconds INR: 0.9 Creatinine: 0.5 mg/dl BUN: 10 mg/dl U/A: Color: yellow Appearance: hazy PH: 5.3 Free weight: 1,010 Glc ((Glycose): 100 Nitrites: negative Ketones: no Leukocyte esterase: negative Glucose: negative WBC: 2 WBC/h Upf/C: negative

Patient is a 42-year-old postmenopausal female with an abnormality in the right breast on the scan ultrasound. There was no mass felt by hand during the breast exam. A core biopsy was performed and a six-inch infiltrating ductal mammary carcinoma was found in the upper left external quadrant. He had a lumpectomy and the surgical boundaries were clear. The tumor was HER2-positive and ER/PR negative. In the axillary sampling, 1 of the 12 lymph nodes sampled showed a positive result. There was nothing remarkable on the CXR. She takes a daily "well women" multivitamin and no other medication. He often smokes and occasionally drinks alcohol. She's only had one partner, and she's had three pregnancies and live births. She nursed all three of her children.

A 45-year-old female patient was sent to the emergency room with abdominal pain, nausea and 2 vomiting attacks that lasted for about 4 days. The pain is localized to the epigastric region and spreading to the right upper quadrant. The pain gets worse after eating fatty foods. The patient has experienced similar pain twice in the past year. His medical history of hypercholesterolemia and two caesarean sections is remarkable. She has two kids and she's menopausal. She doesn't smoke, drink or take illegal drugs. She has a slight fever. BP is 150/85, HR is 115, RR is 15, T is 38.2, SpO2 is 98% in RA. He's feeling epigastric sensitivity on palpation and sensitivity without rebound in the upper right quadrant. His bowel sounds are normal. Lab analysis shows a high ESR and leukocytosis, along with a left shift. Ultrasound detected a few gallstones and gall mud. The largest gallstone is 0.7 cm. Surgical consultation suggests an elective cholecystectomy.

A 53-year-old male patient has been coming in with chronic HCV infection for the past two years. His medical history is only relevant to the hip hernia surgery he had when he was 20. He's been on combination IFN (100 mg a week) plus RBV (400 mg a day) for the last nine months. His treatment was supplemented with direct antiviral drugs six months ago. He has a previously positive HCV RNA test and positive enzyme immunoassay for anti-HCV antibodies in his medical record. The last biopsy was negative for hepatocellular carcinoma and was only notable for chronic inflammation consistent with chronic viral hepatitis. No signs of alcoholic liver disease, bleeding from the esophageal veins, hemochromatosis, autoimmune hepatitis or metabolic liver disease. A man with a clear conscience, no acute distress. Blood pressure is 130 over 75 and heart rate is 90 over the minute and body mass index is 27. His stomach is soft, no acid or tenderness. Lower extremities are normal, no swelling.

Patient is a 60-year-old Hispanic male who arrived with shortness of breath about a day ago. The symptoms started acutely and got progressively worse. He was diagnosed with COPD two years ago. The spirometry showed that the post-bronchodilator FEV1/FVC was 60% of the predicted value. He smokes 20 cigarettes a day. His past medical history is benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) which is why he's taking Flomax. Family history shows that her brother has hypertension (HT) positive. Between his medications, he uses a Duo-Neb inhaled PRN every four hours, 1,000 units of Vitamin D3 a day, and Flomax for PBH. An obese male who is acutely ill, but is oriented and conscious. His vital signs are as follows: BP (Blood pressure): 135/80 RR (Respiratory rate): 25/min RR (Respiratory rate): 25/min HR (Pulse): 75 bpm BMI: 40 O2sat: 90%

The patient is a 24-year-old male with type 1 diabetes for 11 years. He goes to the emergency room with hyperglycemia and concerns about possible diabetic ketoacidosis due to not taking insulin for 3 days. The patient reports that he is currently homeless and has lost his insulin, syringe, glucometer and glucose testing equipment. Patient reports that he was hospitalized with a glucose value >1000 mg/dL when diagnosed with type 1 diabetes. It then experiences polyuria, polydipsia and polyphagia. He reports that he has been using insulin since his diagnosis and has never been prescribed oral medication for diabetes management. The last one uses 55 units of insulin glargine once daily and insulin aspart three times daily on a sliding scale. The patient has had previous episodes of diabetic ketoacidosis, which has resulted in hospitalization. She's not experiencing any nausea, vomiting, or abdominal discomfort during this hyperglycemic attack, and she seems to be doing well. Laboratory tests showed that: A1c: 11.3% Creatine: 0.9 mg/dL, eGFR >60 mL/min Aspartate aminotransferase (AST): 17 U/L Alanin aminotransferase (ALT): 14 U/L Beta-hydroxybutyrate: 0.1 mmol/L Bicarbonate: 25 mEq/L An ion gap: 14 mEq/L The following is the average of the two groups of amino acids in the test:

The patient was a 33-year-old woman who had come in complaining of fatigue, weight gain, and abnormal spotting between periods. No signs of hirsutism or nipple discharge. His body mass index (BMI) was 34. The high level of TSH (13 mU/L) and low free T4 level (0.2 ng/dl) were notable in the laboratory results. His anti-TPO levels were extremely high (120 IU/ml). Hashimoto was diagnosed with thyroiditis. His aunt, brother, and mother had the same disease. After starting Levothyroxine at 250 mcg per day, her symptoms improved significantly and her periods were normal. Patient with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 31 is still overweight. The most recent thyroid profile showed all results except anti-TPO to be in the normal range: TSH: 2.35 mU/L Free T4: 2.7 ng/dl Anti-TPO: 75 IU/ml

Patient is a 37-year-old female who came to the clinic for a routine Pap smear. The test revealed that she had stage 1B cervical cancer. The patient tested positive for HPV 16. He has three sexual partners and four children. He had a tubal ligation. He smokes 30 packs a year and drinks a lot. He's generally healthy. A radical hysterectomy was recommended.

A 17-year-old male has been complaining of vomiting, bloodless diarrhea, abdominal pain, fever, tremors and loss of appetite for the past three days. He ate a salad at a restaurant before his diarrhea started. The physical examination was marked by paleness, jaundice, and a general abdominal tenderness. Laboratory results were as follows: Hemoglobin: 9.7 g/dL Platelets: 110,000 /cu.mm Creatinine: 3.6 mg/dL Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 73 mg/dL Direct bilirubin: 2.4 mg/dL Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH): 881 IU/L (normal: 110-265 IU/L) Medium number of chocyst and helmet cells were seen in the peripheral blood circulation. E. coli (STEC) stx1/stx2 bacteria were found in the feces, producing Shiga-like toxin. She has no other underlying medical conditions and is not taking any medication.

A healthy 42-year-old woman came to the clinic in early October to get her flu shot. She works at a rehab center and has no underlying medical condition. It's the first time this year. She's been married for five years and uses barrier contraception. The menstrual cycle is irregular. He doesn't smoke. He's not on any medication. He exercises regularly for at least 30 minutes a day, five days a week. She's not allergic to any food or medication. Her history of tonsil surgery is significant and generally healthy.

Patient is a 47-year-old Asian woman who complains of a constant feeling of sadness. He has lost interest in the activities he once enjoyed. It indicates that your mood has been mostly depressed for the past three weeks. He also lost his appetite, which led to a loss of about 10 pounds. Almost every day he complains of a loss of energy and a feeling of worthlessness. He doesn't use any drugs and he doesn't smoke. He doesn't drink. He exercised at least 30 minutes every day. But he hasn't had the energy to do that for the last three weeks. He's also been having some digestive problems lately. He is married and father of four children. She's in menopause. His wife was recently diagnosed with colon cancer and started chemotherapy. There's nothing remarkable in his past medical history, and his pharmacological history is only positive for 1,000 units of vitamin D3 daily. There's no family history of psychological problems. HAM-D score is 20.

Patient is a 15-year-old girl with a history of recurrent bilateral headaches. The attacks come twice or more a week, and each attack lasts about a day and a half. The pain is convulsive and severe, and it interferes with routine physical activity. The seizures are associated with nausea and photophobia. She's noticed that she's been having more attacks recently during her period. He's been diagnosed with migraine headaches and is undergoing treatment. She's a high school student and lives with both her parents. He is a book collector and spends his free time in a public library near his home. She is also interested in writing fiction and has several short stories in English. He rarely exercises. Body mass index is 21, blood pressure is 100/60. There's nothing unusual about the physical.

Patient is a 32-year-old obese woman who came to the clinic with weight concerns. He is 5'6", weighs 350. She has sleep apnea, PCOS, and body image discomfort. She's a high school teacher who's been married for five years. She hasn't used any form of birth control in the last four months, and she's never been pregnant before. He doesn't smoke or do drugs. She likes to try dieting and exercise to lose weight. He completed the four-square-step test in 14 seconds. Blood pressure is 130 over 80, heart rate is 195 over the minute, and body mass index is 41.54. Laboratory results: FBS (Famine blood sugar): 98 mg/dl TG: 150 mg/dl Cholesterol: 180 mg/dl LDL: 90 mg/dl HDL: 35 mg/dl Cardiac evaluation was normal. The following are the results of the laboratory tests: Joint and movement clearance are within normal limits.

The patient is a 20-year-old Caucasian woman who has been in the clinic for one day with unilateral vision loss, facial paralysis, dysarthria and numbness. He visited his primary care provider and had an MRI of his brain, which revealed that there was a single plaque in his brain stem. A few months later, she developed weakness in her lower extremities, which led to balance problems. The second MRI showed another lesion in the left cerebral hemisphere. After the second MRI, the diagnosis of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) was confirmed. His surgical history says he had a C-section two years ago and had a child. Divorced and currently not having any sexual relations. He smokes 10 cigarettes a day and drinks alcohol occasionally. She works as an editor at a publishing house and is happy to be able to work from home most of the time. She's been on RRMS for seven months.

Patient is a 35-year-old female with myasthenia gravis (class IIa). She has symptoms of diplopia, fatigue, and weakness, and these symptoms mostly affect her upper extremities. The anti-AChR antibody test was positive and the single-fiber electromyography (SFEMG) was positive. He's on 60 milligrams of pyridostigmine three times a day. But he still has some symptoms that prevent him from doing his job. She's a research coordinator and a mother of three. His 70-year-old father has hypertension. He doesn't smoke or do drugs. He drinks alcohol occasionally at social events. No other abnormalities were found during the physical examination and laboratory tests. Blood pressure: 110/75 Hgb: 11 g/dl Blood count: 8000/mm3 Plt: 300000/ml Creatinine: 0.5 mg/dl BUN: 10 mg/dl Beta hcg: negative for pregnancy and the pregnancy was not successful

A three-day-old Asian baby girl has filed a complaint of jaundice that began the day before. She was born after a very uncomplicated pregnancy at 38 weeks and 3 days. There's nothing special about the family history. The baby is fed with mother's milk. Vital findings: temperature under the seat: 36.3°C, heart rate: 154 beats/min, respiratory rate: 37 breaths/min and blood pressure: 65/33 mm Hg were reported. It weighs 3.2 kg, is 53 cm tall and has a head circumference of 36 cm. Its sclera is yellow and its body is yellow. No bloating or other abnormalities in the heart and lung osculation. Liver and spleen are normal on palpation. Laboratory results are as follows: Serum total bilirubin: 21.02 mg/dL Direct bilirubin: 2.04 mg/dL AST: 37 U/L ALT: 20 U/L GGT: 745 U/L Alkaline phosphatase: 531 U/L Creatinine: 0.3 mg/dL Production: 29 mg/dL Na: 147 mEq/L K: 4.5 mEq/L CRP: 3 mg/L Complete blood count within the normal range. I was diagnosed with uncomplicated neonatal constipation that would require phototherapy.

The patient is a 60-year-old male with recurrent headaches, widespread bone pain, and difficulty chewing that started six years ago and has been getting worse. Examination reveals two-sided swelling around the incisors. The swelling's increased since her last checkup. Head and several percent extraoral lesions were detected. The bumps are not sensitive and are glued to the bone underneath. Further evaluation indicates increased radioactive material retention and an increase in urinary pyridinoline. Serum alkaline phosphatase is 300 IU/L (normal range is 44 to 147 IU/L). Family history only shows her mother with hypertension and her father with type 2 DM. Diagnosis of Paget's bone disease has been confirmed and Bisphosphonate will be initiated as first-line treatment.

A 57-year-old farmer was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease a year ago. He's got a slow movement and a tremor. His medical history has important findings in terms of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He lives with his wife. They have three kids. Before he was diagnosed, he was a farmer and rancher. Patient complains of tremors and slow movement. He was frozen and needed guidance to get inside, so he had difficulty getting through a door. The handwriting is getting smaller. He's on levodopa and trihexyphenidyl. He said his medication helped with tremors and slow movements. But it still experiences difficulty in initiating movements, general arrest and slowness. He's a clear-headed, harmonious man with no signs of dementia. He doesn't smoke or use any illegal drugs.

32 weeks and 6 days pregnant, 19-year-old Hispanic woman with G1P1 complaining of mild headache and leg swelling, has been referred to the maternity clinic for routine check-ups. Blood pressure was 146/99 on initial assessment and 3+ protein on urine bar test. Blood pressure and urine tests were normal at the last exam. A few hours later, his blood pressure was 150/100 mmHg. His lab tests showed normal levels of hematocrit, platelet count, and liver transaminase. She's complaining of fatigue, but no fever or tremors. He also suffers from headaches without any change in vision. There was no shortness of breath, cough, chest pain, orthopaedics, contusions or skin rashes. The physical examination was negative for abdominal pain, altered bowel habits, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, frequent urination, haematuria or foamy urine. The leg swelling was not accompanied by joint pain or back pain. She has no history of any specific health issues and she's only taking prenatal vitamins. He has a family history of type 2 DM and hypertension. He doesn't smoke or do drugs, but he does drink socially. She's only had one partner for the last two years, and she hasn't used any form of birth control for the last two years. At six weeks pregnant, her body mass index was 24 on the first exam. They gain weight normally during their pregnancies.

A 60-year-old female patient admitted to the stroke department recently received intravenous antibiotic treatment for aspiration pneumonia for the second time. He has a fever, complains of abdominal pain and diarrhea (eight bowel movements in 3 hours, large amounts of greenish, liquid stool each time). The patient's abdomen is usually tender and swollen, and her bowel sounds are hyperactive. He has a fever of 38.4 degrees, a tachycardia of 113, and hypotension of 80/40 mmHg. The stool samples are positive for Clostridium difficile toxin.

The patient is a 14-year-old boy who has scoliosis and back pain. No other medical problems. He used to be able to do routine activities like basketball and soccer, but lately he's had a hard time doing those. The pain in your leg, your back, and it gets worse with physical activity. Most of the time, he prefers to lie down. He's not happy with his body movements, complains of shoulder imbalance and tilting his head to the right. The patient is a well-dressed and well-fed, well-adjusted, well-adjusted, well-adjusted adolescent. His left shoulder is a little higher than his right. The scoliosis curve is measured at 45 degrees. Patient is a candidate for scoliosis surgery based on perioperative MEP (Motor Alert Potential) monitoring.

The patient is a 34-year-old African-American male with a known history of sickle cell disease, and he comes to the clinic with severe bone pain. The patient had severe pain in the lower back, which spread to both hips, and scored 9 out of 10 on the pain scale. The patient had a history of sickle cell crisis since childhood. He's also had the same symptoms for the past two weeks, and he's been on oxycodone, which hasn't helped his pain. The family doctor sent him to the ER to get IV pain modulators. The patient's blood pressure is normal and there's no fever. The physical examination was negative for splenomegaly. No history of drug allergy. He doesn't smoke or use illegal drugs. The laboratory work is as follows: Hgb: 8 g/dl WBC: 10000 /mm3 Plt: 300000 /ml MCV: 106 fL Hemoglobin electrophoresis: 91% HbS %6 HbF %3 HbA2 AST: 22 U/L ALT: 43 U/L Alk P: 53 U/L Ferritin: 1200 ng/ml The following is the list of the most commonly used chemicals in the laboratory:

Patient A is a 30-year-old male admitted to hospital with a 10-day bout of cough, excessive night sweats and loss of appetite. He traveled to India a month ago and has no history of positive TB vaccination. He is a previously healthy man and works as an engineer in a high-tech company. He doesn't smoke or use illegal drugs. He had a fever of 38 degrees, a heart rate of 115 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 22, blood pressure of 125/75 mmHg, and O2 saturation of 97%. The spread of the sputum revealed a positive sputum culture for Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which is sensitive to the first-line TB drugs (isoniazid, streptomycin, rifampicin and etambutol). The following laboratory study was reported: Hgb: 13 g/dl WBC: 14000 /mm3 Plt: 300000 /ml AST: 13 U/L ALT: 15 U/L Alk P: 53 U/L Total bilirubin: 0.6 mg/dl Na: 137 mEq/l K: 4 mEq/l Creatinine: 0.5 mg/dl BUN: 10 mg/dl ESR: 120 mm/h The following is a list of the most commonly reported laboratory studies.

A 62-year-old African-American male, with dark-colored vision in his right eye, numbness in his right cheek, facial paralysis and slurred speech, presented with weakness in his left upper and lower extremities. No signs of dyspnea, headache, convulsions, chest pain, fever, dizziness, bowel or urinary retention, loss of consciousness. His medical history had significant findings in terms of hypertension, hyperlipidemia and hypothyroidism. He's been smoking a pack a day for 40 years and drinking five to six beers a week. He doesn't know anything about the family history. He's on Levothyroxine, Atorvastatin and HTCZ. His vitals were stable at first assessment. The physical examination showed facial paralysis on the left side, dysarthria, and hemiplegia on the left side. The National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score was calculated as 7. The first CT angiogram of the head and neck area did not report acute intracranial findings. The patient was treated with intravenous recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA) and high-dose statin therapy. The patient has been admitted to the intensive care unit for 24 hours of follow-up. Headache MRI showed right periventricular white matter and a 1.7 cm acute infarction in the posterior right basal ganglia.

Fernandez is a 41-year-old professional soccer player. She came to the clinic with an itchy foot. Physical examination revealed localized pulsing and maseration between the third and fourth toes of the right toe. It's become inflamed and painful, with minor fractures. The back and the sole of the foot are unaffected. No iridescence or tearing in the affected area. He didn't apply any topical ointments to the lesion and he doesn't have any history of any underlying medical conditions like DM. He smokes 15 cigarettes a day and a beer a day. Family history: mother has hyperlipidemia, father has MI. He has multiple partners and uses condoms during sex. Physical examination and lab work are otherwise normal. The diagnosis of tinea pedis infection was confirmed by observation of segmented fungal hyphae during microscopic KOH wet assembly examination.

A 12-year-old girl came to the clinic with her mother, complaining of short stature, delayed puberty, and stunted growth. The karyotype test was found to be 45X and confirmed the diagnosis of Turner syndrome. She's been on GH therapy without estrogen treatment to avoid menstruation for six months and achieve her ideal complexion. The physical examination revealed that she had a girl who was obese and mentally disabled. Her mammary glands were stage one, no thick hair under the groin or the seat. His last lab test was TSH 3, and his FBS was 75.

A five-month-old male was brought to the pediatric surgery clinic with a complaint of an empty scrotum on the right side. The baby boy was the first child born with NVD (Normal Vaginal Birth) from a healthy mother at 38 weeks. The mother had a normal pregnancy without any complications. The male was 50 cm tall and weighed 3200 grams. The baby, who is breastfed, now weighs 6.5 kg and is 62 cm tall. There was no developmental delay on the physical. I had a testis in my left scrotum that could be examined by hand, and a testis in my right scrotum that could not be examined by hand. The penis was normal in shape and size and uncircumcised. Diagnostic laparoscopy showed an abdominal undescended testicle.

Patient is a 25-year-old G1 P1 pregnant woman with a gestation period of 24 weeks 3 days, with sudden onset of fever and tremor, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. There are also complaints of burning, tightness and frequent urination when urinating. He also reports severe pain in his side. The vital signs are: T (Fire) = 39.7oC, P (Pulse) = 117, R (Respiratory count) = 20 and BP (Tension) = 113/74 mm Hg. The physical examination revealed palpable sensitivity at both costovertebral angles. She has no history of recurrent BSE or other underlying medical conditions prior to her pregnancy. Gram-negative rod-shaped bacterial cells, leukocytes and leukocyte cylinders have been seen in urine culture. Blood culture is negative. The complete blood count (CBC) is Hb 12.9 g/dL, Hct %39, MCV 76 fL, WBC count is 14.120/μL.

A 34-year-old man comes into the clinic complaining of dizziness and severe diarrhea that started yesterday. He just got back from a trip abroad a few days ago and has been living in a camp in Sudan for a month. He developed abdominal pain, bloating and nausea, and complaints of loose stools. Soon, he had a smellless, watery diarrhea. The stool was watery and white, but the patient had no fever. Blood pressure drops to 95/62 when you're lying down, 75/40 when you're standing up. Her skin was down. He seemed weak with a heart rate of 110 and a dry mucosa. The dark-field microscopy of the fresh stool sample showed V. cholerae. The laboratory work is as follows: Sodium 137 meq/L Potassium 2 meq/L Chloride 94 meq/L CO2 15 meq/L No leukocytes found in faeces Hidden blood in faeces Negative

The patient, a 34-year-old Jordanian woman, comes to the clinic with general, non-specific bone and joint pain. Married with three kids. There's no significant findings in the history of medicine and pharmaceuticals. Body mass index is 23, blood pressure is 120/75, heart rate is 75/min. Laboratory results indicate a vitamin D content of 14 ng/ml and that the patient is in good general health (Ca: 9.2 mg/dl, Phosphorus: 3.2 mg/dl, PTH: 28 pg/ml).

A 57-year-old male patient came to the clinic four months ago with weight loss and a persistent dry cough. In the computed topography of the chest, bilateral infiltrates and thickened bronchial walls were seen in the upper lobes. His medical records documented a positive serum MPO-ANCA. Multiple nucleated giant cell necrotic granulomas were seen in the transbronchial biopsy and the patient was diagnosed with Wegener granulomatosis. He's been on corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide for four months. Birmingham Vasculitis Activity Score (BVAS) has been above 4 since the onset of his illness. The final physical examination and laboratory examination were performed yesterday and the results were as follows: A healthy, well-nourished, unclothed, fit and conscious male Weight: 73 kg Height: 177 Blood pressure: 120/80 Heart rate-minute: 90/sec Respiratory rate-minute: 22/sec Hgb: 13 g/dl Bladder count: 8000/mm3 (Nutrophil: 2700/mm3) Plt: 300,000/ml AST: 40 U/L ALT: 56 U/L Alcohol: 147 U/L Total body mass index: 1.2 mg/dl RSI: 120 mm/day MPOCA-AN: EU 153

A 22-year-old Caucasian male came to the clinic with a history of tremors that began a year ago. The tremor first started in his right hand when he was holding something. Then the tremor became persistent, spreading to both arms and legs, a tremor that lasted while he was at rest. The eye exam showed a Kaiser-Fleischer ring. Physical examination showed jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly and hypotonia in the upper extremities. He had a constant smile on his face, but his family described him as aggressive. In laboratory studies, a significant increase in low serum seruloplasmin (0.05 g/l) and 24-hour urine copper clearance (120 μg/24 h) was found. Wilson's disease was confirmed by high liver copper concentration (305 μg/g dry liver weight).

Patient is a 41-year-old male with a known case of acromegaly who underwent transsphenoidal surgery four months ago. After the primary resection, she came to the clinic for follow-up lab tests. In the lab test, the IGF-1 level adjusted for gender and age is 4.5 ULN. Random GH level is 4 ug/L. His last brain MRI confirmed a residual pituitary tumor. His medical history is acromegaly associated with pituitary adenoma only, and he recently had surgery. After the surgery, she's only taking vitamin D and a multivitamin.

Patient is a 41-year-old obese woman who came to the emergency room with abdominal pain and vomiting. The pain that started slowly yesterday is localized to the epigastric and peri-umbilical regions, spreading to the back. He often drinks alcohol and does not smoke. No history of allergies and only takes a daily multivitamin. Her family history is positive for hypertension. He lives with his wife and has 3 children. Your wife is delicate and soft. His bowel sounds are normal. His heart rate is 115 beats per minute and his blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. Laboratory tests showed a leukocytosis (19.5), urea 8.5, high CRP (145), high amylase (1200) and glucose level of 15. A CT scan of the abdomen revealed enlarged common bile duct and intrahepatic duct with acute edema of the interstitial pancreatitis, confirming gallstone pancreatitis. Her pregnancy test came back negative, and she's not breastfeeding.

Patient is a 17-year-old male with severe, seizure-like pain in the right lower quadrant of his abdomen, which began four days ago. The pain is accompanied by nausea and vomiting. He had fire, precision, rebound precision and defense on the palpation. High white blood cell count and predominant neutrophils. CT scan showed signs of acute perforectomy with free fluid in the pelvis. Diagnostic laparoscopy showed phlegmon and no other abdominal abnormalities. The patient is currently under general anesthesia and is a candidate for an emergency laparoscopic appendectomy.

The patient is a 15-year-old boy who was diagnosed with asthma a year ago. She complained of shortness of breath, chest tightness and coughing. According to his mother, he didn't respond to the usual corticosteroid inhalations. She was admitted to the emergency room with severe asthma flare-ups. General corticosteroid therapy is recommended. Spirometry showed that the forced expiratory volume (FEV1) in the first second was 60% of the predicted one. There's nothing serious in his medical history. Family history is important in terms of asthma in his mother and uncle. He was previously treated with a combination of inhaled corticosteroids and Zafirlukast.

The patient is a 63-year-old male who has been in the ER for the past two days with acute urinary retention. Abdominopelvic CT scan found a large prostate and a bladder full of urine. The patient is a candidate for urethral catheterization and TURP. Further evaluations revealed the following: Residue after urination: 71 mL Prostate volume (TRUS): 63 mL Prostate specific antigen (PSA) level: 3.5 ng/mL Final blood biochemistry (3 days ago) was normal: Hgb: 13.6 g/dl WBC: 133000 /mm3 Plt: 370000 /ml PT: 12 seconds PTT: 34 seconds INR: 0.9 Creatinine: 0.5 mg/dl BUN: 10 mg/dl U/A: Color: yellow Appearance: dull PH: 5.3 Weight of the specimen: 1.010 Glc: 100 Nitrites: negative Ketone: no Leukocyte esterase: negative Alvary: WBC: negative 2 WBC/hpf UBC/C: negative

Patient is a 45-year-old postmenopausal woman who has been diagnosed with cytologic breast cancer. A thick needle biopsy revealed invasive ductal breast carcinoma in the left upper quadrant, three centimeters in diameter. The tumor is HER2 positive and ER/PR negative. We found five positive lymph nodes in the axillary sampling. Metastatic lesions are notable in CXR. The patient is taking a multivitamin and an iron supplement. He doesn't smoke or drink. He's not sexually active and he doesn't have any children. He's a candidate for tumor resection and he's willing to have it removed before chemotherapy.

A 46-year-old male patient came in complaining of dizziness and frequent headaches. She had a family history of coronary artery disease, but no other cardiovascular risk factors such as smoking, high blood pressure and diabetes mellitus, and was physically active. The patient's LDL-K and HDL-K levels were 545 and 53 mg/dL, respectively. His fasting blood sugar and triglyceride levels (85 and 158 mg/dL, respectively) were within normal limits. The patient reported no lipid-lowering drugs. Neck osculation found 3+/6+ systolic blows extending to the neck and skull. Ultrasound of the carotid arteries revealed severe narrowing in the left internal carotid artery (LICA) and moderate narrowing in the right internal carotid artery (RICA), estimated to be between 40% and 50%. For LICA, the peak systolic (PSV) and diastolic end velocity (EDV) cut-off values were 208.5 cm/s and 54.5 cm/s, respectively; RICA PSV was 91.72 cm/s and RICA EDV was 37.37 cm/s. Plaque was observed in the anterior and posterior walls of the internal carotid artery and common carotid artery, characterized by volume plaques extending up to the middle third of the internal coronary arteries (ICAs), and was predominantly ecogenic and hypercootic, with less than 50% of the area occupied by adhesive and irregular surfaces.

A 54-year-old obese woman called the emergency room with complaints of abdominal pain, which began four days ago with nausea and vomiting. The epigastric pain was spreading to the right upper quadrant and getting worse after eating fatty foods. The patient has experienced similar pain twice in the past year. His past medical history was hypercholesterolemia and 2 NVDs. She had two kids and was menopausal. He didn't smoke, drink or use illegal drugs. He had a slight fever. RA (room conditions) blood pressure was 150/85, HR (pulse) 115, RR (respiratory rate) 15, T (Fever) 38.2, SpO2 was 98%. She was an obese woman with no acute distress. On palpation, he felt epigastric sensitivity without rebound and sensitivity in the right upper quadrant. His bowel sounds were normal. In the lab analysis, high ESR and leukocytosis were noted along with left shift. Ultrasound revealed several gallstones, gallbladder sludge and a stone from the CBD. The smallest stone is 14 mm.

Patient is a 55-year-old male who was diagnosed with HCV two years ago and recently co-infected with HBV. His medical history is irrelevant. He's been on IFN, RBV, and direct antiviral drugs for the last six months. The patient is not taking any other medication. In her medical records, she had previously seen positive HCV RNA tests and a positive enzyme immunoassay for anti-HCV antibodies. The last biopsy was negative for hepatocellular carcinoma and was only notable for chronic inflammation consistent with chronic viral hepatitis. There is no evidence of alcoholic liver disease, bleeding from the esophageal veins, hemochromatosis, autoimmune hepatitis or metabolic liver disease. He's a clear-eyed man with no acute distress. BP is 130/75, HR is 90/minute and BMI is 27. His stomach is soft, no acid or tenderness. There's no swelling in the lower extremities.

The patient is a 25-year-old male with type 1 diabetes, confirmed by molecular analysis seven years ago. She comes to the clinic complaining of shortness of breath and fatigue during activities. He claims to have experienced a mild shortness of breath after ascending 3 flights, no resting breathing difficulties, and no angina (New York Heart Association class 2). He's been diagnosed with cardiomyopathy, which needs to be treated with ACE inhibitors and beta blockers. She's on 70/30 insulin and vitamin D. No other medical history. His uncle and grandfather have a family history of type 1 DM. The laboratory results are as follows: FBS (Famine Blood Sugar): 100 mg/dl HbA1c: 6.5% Cholesterol: 190 mg/dl TG: 140 mg/dl LDL: 125 mg/dl HDL: 40 mg/dl

A 16-year-old girl came to the clinic complaining of weight gain and irregular menstrual cycles. Although his BMI was 24, he had gained five pounds in the last few weeks. He was getting tired more often and didn't have the energy to go dancing with his friends. High TSH levels (15 mU/L) and low free T4 levels (0.18 ng/dl) were notable in the laboratory results. His anti-TPO levels were extremely high (136 IU/ml). He was diagnosed with Hashimoto's disease. She doesn't smoke and she's not sexually active.

A Pap smear on a 54-year-old woman has revealed abnormal cervical squamous intraepithelial/glandular lesions. HPV 16 is positive. He has sex with his wife and has four children. She's in menopause and not using any form of birth control. He often smokes and drinks. He's generally healthy. Connization is recommended.

The patient is a 23-year-old male who was admitted to hospital with high blood pressure (175/95 mmHg) and septicaemia. Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation and renal failure requiring hemodialysis have developed. Microangiopathic haemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia have been detected in the bloodstream. Blood tests showed a normal clotting profile with elevated lactate dehydrogenase and low levels of human complement C3. The patient has been diagnosed with atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome. He's been treated with plasma exchange and corticosteroids. The meningococcal ACWY conjugate vaccine and the meningococcal B vaccine have been administered previously. It was found to be ADAMTS13 > 10% in the genetic analysis.

A healthy 67-year-old woman came to the clinic in early October to get her flu shot. She works at a rehab center and has no underlying medical condition. First shot this year. She's menopausal and has four kids. He doesn't have any allergies. He's on a daily multivitamin and a hypertensive medication. He exercises regularly for at least 30 minutes a day, five days a week. She's not allergic to any food or medication.

46-year-old Asian woman with MDD (Major Depressive Disorder) complaining of persistent feelings of sadness and loss of interest in daily activities. He says that his mood is still depressed most days. Almost every day he complains of a loss of energy and a feeling of worthlessness. She's been on antidepressants for the last six months, but the symptoms are still present. He doesn't drink or smoke. He exercised at least 30 minutes a day, but he hasn't had the energy to do it for the last three weeks. And he's been having some digestive issues lately. She's married with four kids. She's in menopause. Her husband was diagnosed with colon cancer a year ago and is undergoing chemotherapy. There's nothing remarkable about his past medical history. There's no family history of psychological problems. The HAM-D score is 20.

The patient is a 34-year-old obese woman who came to the clinic with weight concerns. He is 165 cm tall and weighs 113 kg (BMI: 41.5). He's tried anti-obesity drugs and appetite suppressants before, but they've all failed. She has sleep apnea, PCOS, and body image discomfort. He's a high school teacher. She's been married for five years. She hasn't used any form of birth control in the last four months, and she's never been pregnant before. He rarely exercises and has difficulty moving. He can't complete the four-square-step test in less than 15 seconds. He doesn't smoke or do drugs. Blood pressure is 130 over 80, heart rate is 195 over the minute, and his BMI is 41.54. Lab results: FBS (Famine blood sugar): 98 mg/dl TG: 150 mg/dl Cholesterol: 180 mg/dl LDL: 90 mg/dl HDL: 35 mg/dl Laparoscopic gastric bypass surgery is being considered

Patient is a 16-year-old girl who was recently diagnosed with myasthenia gravis, grade iia. He's got double vision and weakness in his upper extremities. The anti-AChR antibody test was positive and the single-fiber electromyography (SFEMG) was positive. He's being treated with an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor along with immunosuppressive drugs. But he still has some symptoms. He doesn't smoke or do drugs. She's not sexually active and her periods are regular. No other abnormalities were found during the physical examination and laboratory tests. Blood pressure: 110/75 Hgb: 11 g/dl Blood count: 8000/mm3 Plt: 300000/ml Creatinine: 0.5 mg/dl BUN: 10 mg/dl Beta hcg: negative for pregnancy and the pregnancy was not successful

Patient is a 3-day-old girl with a cough that started the day before. She was born at 34 weeks and kept in a vat because of her gestational age. Life-cycle data: temperature under the seat: 36.3°C, heart rate: 154 beats/min, respiratory rate: 37 breaths/min and blood pressure: 65/33 mm Hg are reported. It weighs 2.1 kg, is 45 cm tall and has a head circumference of 32 cm. It's yellow sclera and yellow corpus. Liver and spleen are normal with palpation. Laboratory results are as follows: Serum total bilirubin: 21.02 mg/dL Direct bilirubin: 2.04 mg/dL AST: 37 U/L ALT: 20 U/L GGT: 745 U/L Alkaline phosphatase: 531 U/L Creatinine: 0.3 mg/dL Production: 29 mg/dL Na: 147 mEq/L K: 4.5 mEq/L CRP: 3 mg/L Complete blood count within the normal range. I've been diagnosed with neonatal constipation, which may require phototherapy.

Patient is a 53-year-old male with recurrent headaches, widespread bone pain, and difficulty chewing that started six years ago and has been getting worse. Examination reveals two-sided swelling around the incisors. The swelling's increased since her last checkup. Head and several percent extraoral lesions were detected. The bumps are not sensitive and are glued to the bone underneath. Further evaluation indicates increased radioactive material retention and an increase in urinary pyridinoline. Serum alkaline phosphatase is 300 IU/L (normal range is 44 to 147 IU/L). The patient's sister had the same problems. She was diagnosed with Paget's disease of bone at the age of 52. Diagnosis of Paget's bone disease has been confirmed and Bisphosphonate will be initiated as first-line treatment.

Patient is a 55-year-old male recently diagnosed with Parkinson's disease. Complains of slow movement and tremors. His condition is mild, Hoehn-Yahr stage I. His medical history has important findings in terms of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He lives with his wife. They have three kids. He was actively gardening before he was diagnosed. She's complaining of tremors and slow movement. He was frozen and needed guidance to get inside, so he had trouble getting through a door. The handwriting is getting smaller. He's being prescribed Levodopa and Trihexyphenidyl. A man who's alert and cooperative, showing no signs of dementia. He doesn't smoke or use any illegal drugs.
